title: Business News: Tesla Lowers Prices of Models in China --- Move comes as Musk says material costs are dropping, and with rivals gaining in market
content:
HONG KONG -- Tesla Inc. has lowered prices for vehicles sold in China, days after Chief Executive Elon Musk said most materials costs are falling and amid growing competition from local rivals.
Prices for Tesla's popular Models Y and 3 sold in China, the world's biggest electric-vehicle market, have been cut by as much as 9.4%, according to a social-media post by the company Monday. A standard Model Y now costs the equivalent of $39,880, down from about $43,750, while the long-range version has an even bigger discount. A standard Model 3 fetches about $36,710, down by about $1,930.
The company has overcome production glitches and is seeing lower input costs but is facing greater competition amid a gloomy global economic outlook. Surging sales of new-energy vehicles are also driving intense competition for lithium, the key ingredient in vehicle batteries.
The discounts restore the models' price ranges closer to levels in early March. Tesla and other car manufacturers in China raised prices several times in the past year to adjust for increases in costs as the price of lithium almost tripled and they were ensnared by supply-chain delays. Tesla also raised prices for cars sold in the U.S. several times this year, citing inflationary pressure in materials and logistics.
Tesla didn't respond to a request for further comment.
Shares of Tesla closed down 1.5% to $211.25 on Monday. The drop comes as the stocks of U.S.-listed Chinese tech companies such as Alibaba, Baidu, JD.com and Pinduoduo fell by double-digit percentages following Xi Jinping's deepening his control over the world's second-largest economy this past weekend.
Mr. Musk, during a call with analysts last week to discuss the company's earnings, said that prices of most commodities are set to fall next year, which would lower costs, and warned of a "brutal recession" ahead. Prices for steel and aluminum have dropped while shipping container rates from Shanghai have collapsed, other company executives added.
Still, when asked whether Tesla would adjust its prices globally, Mr. Musk said only that the company was watching its costs closely. Lithium prices remained "crazy expensive," he said.
Production conditions for China's car makers have returned to normal in recent months as delays in the supply chain caused by Beijing's stringent Covid-19 controls were smoothed out. Demand, however, remained weak, with retail car sales from August to September growing at their slowest pace in decades, according to the China Passenger Car Association's monthly release.
Tesla's Shanghai plant broke delivery records in September. The world's leading EV maker by units sold faces stiff competition from China's biggest EV car maker, BYD Co. The Shenzhen-based company in the past six months has outsold Tesla in its home market and is targeting global expansion as it pivots away from traditional internal combustion engines to focus solely on new-energy vehicles.
Tesla delivered more than 83,000 vehicles from its factory in China last month, up 8% from August. Globally, the company sold 908,600 over the first nine months of this year after ramping up production at its Shanghai factory in July. The factory in Shanghai accounted for more than half of its global production during this period.
Credit: By Selina Cheng

title: Tesla Stock Price Targets March Lower as Bearish Options Activity Moves Higher
content:
This is quite a week for Tesla and CEO Elon Musk . More drama is coming.
For Tesla (ticker: TSLA), Wall Street analysts keep adjusting stock target prices lower following earnings . They are worried about demand.
For Musk, he is supposed to close his Twitter (TWTR) purchase by the end of the week to avoid a Delaware trial. That most likely means more Tesla stock sales from the CEO coming, essentially, now. The potential pending sale has traders circling, trying to make a quick buck.
Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas cut his Tesla price target to $330 from $350 a share. There are several things on his mind including a stronger dollar hurting Tesla sales. (Sales in other currencies such as the euro are worth less in U.S. dollars in that scenario).
With Jonas' cut, the average analyst price target for Tesla shares is down to about $285 from about $301 just before the company reported earnings on Oct. 19.
Along with foreign exchange, Jonas is also worried about demand. "Many of our clients do not believe Tesla is vulnerable to a slowing consumer due to the company's unique position in the EV market and a general lack of supply," wrote Jonas. He disagreed. "Tesla's increasingly large size today and in the forecast makes it susceptible to what could be some profound swings in consumer strength."
He kept his Buy rating. Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi , for his part, rates Tesla shares Sell. He has a $150 price target on the stock. Sacconaghi wrote Tuesday about demand too. He is worried that Tesla demand in China is waning, citing Tesla's recent price cuts in that country.
Falling demand is a huge long-term issue, but it's probably not what is driving some recent trading activity in short-dated Tesla stock options. On Monday, 144,858 Tesla put option contracts that expire on Friday with a $200 strike price exchanged hands. That contract traded 40,632 contracts on Friday.
That's a big jump for an option that only pays off if prices close below $200 a share. Tesla stock was at almost $218 in Tuesday trading, up 3% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively.
(Options traders don't have to hold contract to expiry and can benefit from volatility too).
Holding those contracts seems risky. Traders seem to be betting that Tesla stock price will fall because Elon Musk is likely to sell a large block of stock to fund his Twitter buyout . Musk has only a few days to sell what could be $5 billion to $10 billion in Tesla stock. He's already sold about $15 billion in Tesla stock since making an offer to acquire Twitter and has arranged $30-plus billion in total funds to facilitate his takeover.
Large stock sales can drive down share prices for a time, but it's hard to predict how much and how long especially when everyone knows a stock sale is coming. What's more, Musk has more ways to raise money than just selling stock. He can use additional equity from third parties, margin loans or other deals struck with financiers.
Where Tesla stock will close the week is anyone's guess. All the fundamental research following earnings along with all the trading activity tied to Twitter news is almost certain to make the rest of the week wild for Tesla stock traders and long-term investors.

title: What is the richest country in the world? Is it China? Here's what the numbers show.
content: Economic wealth can be a prime statistic to measure whether a country is growing economically and moving forward, according to Investopedia. Gross domestic product trends can also be utilized to identify economic recessions. Another measurable statistic to track a country’s success is GDP per capita. This calculates a nation’s GDP, but accounts for its population as well, enabling a closer look at the economic strength of each citizen. What is the richest country in the world? Where does the United States stand? What about China? Just Curious?: We're here to help with life's everyday questions. What is the richest country in the world by GDP? As of 2021, the richest country in the world by GDP is the United States, according to the World Bank Group. The U.S. has a GDP of $22.996 trillion, paired with a GDP per capita of $69,287. The U.S. makes up 23.93% of the total global economy, says Investopedia. The World Bank Group lists China as the second richest country in the world as of 2021, possessing a GDP of $17.734 trillion along with a GDP per capita of $12,556.3. China makes up 18.45% of the total global economy. The top two richest countries in the world combined harbor 42.38% of the world’s economy. The third richest country in the world by GDP is Japan at $4.937 trillion in GDP and a $39,285.2 GDP per capita. According to the International Monetary Fund, GDP is “the monetary value of final goods and services…produced in a country in a given period of time (say a quarter or a year).” GDP is commonly used to measure a country’s economic wealth. What is the richest country in the world by GDP per capita? Monaco is the richest country in the world when measured by GDP per capita, according to the World Bank Group. Monaco possesses a $173,688.20 GDP per capita, based on its most recent value in 2020. Liechtenstein, based on 2019 figures, held a $169,049.20 GDP per capita, making it the second richest country in the world when calculating GDP per capita. Luxembourg is the third richest country in the world when calculating GDP per capita. As of 2021, it measured at $135,682.8. GDP per capita represents “a country’s economic output per person,” according to Investopedia, and it is found by dividing the country’s GDP by its population. The best of the best: Revealed! The best country in the world The world's happiest countries: Europe dominates the list. Who is the richest person in the world? Elon Musk is the richest person in the world, with a total net worth of $254 billion as of August 2022, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.  Elon Musk is the chief executive of multiple companies, including Tesla, which reached a $1 trillion market cap, Space X and Neuralink, says Business Insider. The fight against climate change: These countries have the most polluted air in the world, new report says This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: What is the richest country in the world? Is it China? Here's what the numbers show.

title: Elon Musk Visits Twitter as $44 Billion Deal Nears Completion
content:
In an undated image provided by Delaware Chancery Court, Judge Kathaleen St. J. McCormick, top center, at the Delaware Chancery Court in September. The judge has given Elon Musk until Friday, Oct. 28, 2022, to close his long-promised, $44 billion deal to acquire Twitter. (Delaware Chancery Court via The New York Times) — NO SALES; FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY. —
Elon Musk appears to be on track to close his blockbuster $44 billion deal for Twitter.
Musk, who runs Tesla and SpaceX, visited Twitter’s San Francisco headquarters Wednesday and tweeted a nine-second video of himself smiling and carrying a porcelain sink into the building.
“Entering Twitter HQ — let that sink in!” he wrote.
Musk, the world’s richest man, faces a Friday deadline to complete his purchase of Twitter, according to a judicial ruling. He is expected to attend a variety of meetings this week at the social media company, said three Twitter employees who spoke on the condition of anonymity. He is also set to address Twitter employees Friday, according to the employees and an internal note from Leslie Berland, the company’s chief marketing officer.
Musk, 51, also changed his profile on Twitter by describing himself as “Chief Twit” and marking his location as “Twitter HQ.”
A Twitter spokesperson didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.
Musk’s appearance at Twitter’s offices suggests that he plans to close the deal after a drawn-out and tumultuous few months. The billionaire agreed to buy the company in April. But within weeks, he appeared to regret his decision and tried to back out.
Twitter then sued Musk to force him to abide by the deal contract, with the case scheduled to go to trial this month. This month, the billionaire changed his mind again and recommitted himself to the purchase. The Delaware Chancery Court judge in the case delayed the trial, giving a deadline of Oct. 28 for the deal’s completion.
Musk has promised to transform Twitter by taking it private, doing layoffs and nurturing subscription businesses. He has said he is a “free speech absolutist” and wants to loosen rules around content moderation on the service, including reversing the ban on former President Donald Trump from the platform. He has added that Twitter should become an “everything app” modeled after WeChat, a Chinese platform that offers social media, instant messaging and mobile payments.
Musk has spent the past three weeks finalizing the terms of his financing for the deal, which includes $12.5 billion in debt from Wall Street banks. Investment banks typically sell the debt they arrange for such deals to minimize risk that sits on their balance sheets. But given the quick pace at which Musk is now racing to close the deal, as well as the soured market for such debt, they are instead keeping that debt on their balance sheets at least for the time being, two people with knowledge of the situation said.
With so much uncertainty swirling over the deal, some of Twitter’s 7,500 employees have been jittery. Last week, the company sought to quell employee concerns after reports that Musk planned to lay off as many as 75% of them. Twitter told workers that the current management had no plans for layoffs but could make no promises about what Musk might do.
Employees who hope to remain at the company have also worried that their compensation might change. Under the terms of his agreement to buy Twitter, Musk assented to replace the stock options granted to employees with regularly scheduled cash bonuses. But because Musk has flip-flopped on other deal logistics, some employees have feared that he might not honor his compensation commitments.
On Wednesday, Berland encouraged Twitter’s employees to greet Musk if they saw him in the office.
“If you’re in SF and see him around, say hi!” she wrote in an email, which was obtained by The New York Times.
Musk last spoke with Twitter’s workers during a question-and-answer session in June.
“I want Twitter to contribute to a better, long-lasting civilization where we better understand the nature of reality,” he said at that meeting.
This article originally appeared in The New York Times.
FILE — Outside Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco, Oct. 12, 2022. Elon Musk arrived at Twitter’s San Francisco offices on Wednesday, Oct. 26, 2022, as he faces a Friday deadline to complete the acquisition of the social media service. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)
In an undated image provided by Delaware Chancery Court, Judge Kathaleen St. J. McCormick being sworn in as chancellor of the Delaware Chancery Court as her daughter, Fiona Fawcett, holds a Bible in 2021. The judge has given Elon Musk until Friday, Oct. 28, 2022, to close his long-promised, $44 billion deal to acquire Twitter. (Delaware Chancery Court via The New York Times) — NO SALES; FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY. —

title: This Fund Has Found the Sweet Spot Between Growth and Value
content:
Professional investors often call mid-cap stocks the sweet spot between small- and large-cap stocks. They have the high growth potential of small companies but the stability and lower risk of blue-chips.
If that's true, John Roth and Nicola Stafford are in the sweet spot of that sweet spot. As the managers of the $6.6 billion Fidelity Mid-Cap Stock Fund (ticker: FMCSX), they favor neither the most overvalued growth companies nor the cheapest and, often, most financially distressed ones. They sit right in the middle between growth and value investing as a Mid-Cap Blend fund in Morningstar's fund category style box.
By seeking growth but paying close attention to valuation, the duo has triumphed. In the last five years Fidelity Mid-Cap Stock has beaten 95% of its peers in the Mid Blend category, with a 9.2% annualized return, versus the category average's 6.2%. In 2022's brutal bear market, Mid-Cap Stock has held up well, down 10%, versus the category's minus 17.5% average. The fund's 0.85% expense ratio is below average for its category.
Both Roth, 52, and Stafford, 42, are MIT grads and share an engineer's mind-set toward building a better mousetrap to balance both risk and reward in the fund's portfolio. "I went to MIT undergrad to do mechanical engineering because I was drawn to everything about it," Stafford says. "My favorite book as a child was The Way Things Work," a popular illustrated guide to how all sorts of machines and tools—lasers, cars, computers, zippers, etc.—work. Roth was the first person from Fidelity to interview Stafford at MIT while she was still trying to determine her career path.
"It was after meeting John and learning more about what investment management was, that I saw so many parallels between what drew me to engineering and what this job would be," Stafford says. "Every day we try to understand industries. We try to not only break [the industry] down into what matters today, but to think about the future and anticipate who's well positioned and who's not." Stafford is a Fidelity lifer; she has worked there since she started her career in 2001.
That Stafford was Roth's protégé from the start and his colleague for over 20 years is important as she will be taking over as the fund's sole manager when Roth retires at the end of 2022. She says the fund's "investment philosophy and strategy, which John and I have built together, on behalf of our many shareholders" will remain the same. "The fund will continue to be supported by Fidelity's team of hundreds of equity research analysts globally."
Roth was initially a stock trader but joined Fidelity as a summer intern while at MIT, then full-time in 1999 when he graduated. "I went the opposite way of trading, which is a [short-term] tactic to make money," he says. "Investing is where you can bring to bear a long-term perspective."
That perspective is evident in the fund's low 17% portfolio turnover ratio, meaning the average stock is held for over five years. Roth's and Stafford's buy-and-hold philosophy applies to every kind of company. Their eclectic portfolio consists of energy stocks like Hess (HES) and Cheniere Energy (LNG), which are found in many value funds, but here they are held beside growth names like Elon Musk's SpaceX, a nonpublic investment.
Investing in mid-caps in the energy sector is advantageous, Roth says, because he can target specific subindustries. Large integrated oil companies like Exxon (XOM), are too diffuse in their industry exposure. Roth likes Cheniere because of its focus on liquefied natural gas or LNG. "Nobody wants LNG facilities in the U.S., but it's a critical asset," he says. "It allows producers to convert the commodity to a medium that can be shipped globally." Today, with the fighting in Ukraine and sanctions against Russia, Europe wants U.S. natural gas.
Similarly, Hess has a major offshore oil field discovery in Guyana, Roth says. Exxon has oil interests there too, but it has little impact on its bottom line as a giant company. So, Hess benefits more from its focus. Another favorite, Energy Transfer (ET), owns a gas pipeline . "It's very difficult to add pipelines and expand pipelines in the U.S. right now," Roth says. "So, they have this infrastructure that is not replaceable. It also generates a lot of cash, and [the stock] has an 8% dividend yield." Having such unique assets gives companies a competitive edge.
On the growth side of the spectrum is SpaceX. A private rocket company , it was founded by Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla; the fund formerly owned Tesla until it grew too big to be a mid-cap. "Because Mid-Cap Stock owned Tesla, we got to know Elon Musk and understand him as a business person," Roth says. Seeing the engineering and business difficulties Tesla overcame building a scalable electric-car business, gave Roth confidence that a rocket one was "pretty easy" in comparison: "The secret sauce at SpaceX is this ability to reuse the first-stage booster. That saves a tremendous amount of cost in the process."
Roth and Stafford acquired 1.4 million private SpaceX shares between April 2016 and September 2017 for $14.3 million. As of the fund's annual report dated April 30, 2022, those shares were worth $78.2 million. Because private equity is illiquid, typically such investments are only a few percentage points of the portfolio, 3% recently, but they can add oomph to returns.
Despite 2022's downturn, the team has struggled to find publicly traded tech stocks that meet their valuation criteria. "That's an area where since I joined the fund, we've been systematically lightening up," Stafford says. As of Sept. 30, the fund's tech weighting was 6.7%, versus 12.4% for its benchmark, the S&P MidCap 400.
One tech favorite is WNS (WNS), a global IT and business-process outsourcing company based in Mumbai. "In this uncertain [economic] environment, it has an appealing business model," Stafford says. "We think demand is going to stay resilient, as clients increasingly focus on cost savings, which lends itself to outsourcing. It has defensive characteristics at a reasonable valuation."
Resilient would also describe Mid-Cap Stock's record as it tries to balance growth stocks like WNS and inexpensive value ones like Energy Transfer.

title: Musk's Twitter Deal Is Happening. Can His Magic Work on the Tech World?
content:
It's happening. Elon Musk's bankers have fallen into line, helping the billionaire and Tesla CEO secure financing for his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter.
Shares have climbed close to the sale price of $54.20. That suggests that investors see only the slightest chance that the deal will fall through before the court-ordered deadline of Friday.
It may have been a long and winding road to get here, with arguments over bots and Musk's attempts to back out. But the takeover couldn't come at a better time. The sector needs a boost.
Technology companies are having a rough ride . Google parent Alphabet missed earnings expectations for the third quarter as advertising took a hit. Microsoft beat expectations, but still fell on concerns that the cloud computing unit Azure is facing a slowdown. Microchip maker Texas Instruments, typically the bellwether for the industry, sounded the alarm as well. Facebook parent Meta and Amazon are reeling before they even report results.
The most frightening thing is perhaps that there's plenty of room for stocks to fall further. Goldman Sachs analysts wrote in an Oct. 25 note that markets haven't actually priced in a U.S. recession. That means that shares could take another sizeable leg down if the economy doesn't achieve a soft landing.
Musk is usually never shy about doling out advice. Twitter has been criticized by lots of people for failing to make more money from its wide user base.
Now is Musk's big chance to shine. Unfortunately, taking Twitter private might mean that we won't know much about what he actually does until he decides to make it public again.
—Brian Swint
*** Join MarketWatch Deputy Enterprise Editor Jillian Berman and Institute of Student Loan Advisors Founder Betsy Mayotte today at noon to discuss the latest student loan news after the Biden Administration recently released its application for debt relief, while legal challenges are still pending and the Education Department implements other reforms. We'll also take your questions. Sign up here .
***
Elon Musk Faces Friday Deadline to Close Twitter Acquisition
Elon Musk has until 5 p.m. Eastern time on Friday to close his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter or face a legal battle in Delaware Chancery Court next month. Wall Street likely won't be comfortable until control of the company officially changes hands, amid concerns it could still unravel last-minute.
* On Tuesday, Reuters reported that Musk has told co-investors in the deal, including Sequoia Capital, Binance, and Qatar Investment Authority, that he plans to close the deal by Friday. Bloomberg reported Musk told bankers handling the $13 billion in financing he would close by then.
* The financing means Twitter is adding debt to its books, which analysts estimate could put Twitter's annual interest payments above $1 billion. Twitter has in the past five years averaged annual earnings of about $700 million before interest, taxes and depreciation, The Wall Street Journal reported .
* Twitter aims to boost revenue, expand profit and wring out more efficiencies. Twitter significantly slowed hiring in the second quarter, and Musk's lawyers have written in court filings that economic uncertainty could necessitate job cuts to control costs.
* Banks are facing paper losses of $500 million on the debt they are arranging in the deal, the Journal reported. They aren't selling it right away as a buyout financing might normally be syndicated. Instead, by holding it on their books they can wait until market pricing improves.
What's Next: Roy Behren, co-president and co-chief investment officer at Westchester Capital Management, told Barron's that the deal is likely to close by or shortly after Friday's deadline, noting that the Delaware court judge "has shown no patience for Musk's team's tactics."
— Connor Smith and Janet H. Cho 
***
Google's Alphabet Hit by Weakness in YouTube, Search Ads
Google parent Alphabet posted its fifth-consecutive quarter of slowing revenue growth. It was its lowest sales growth since mid-2020 amid a slump in digital advertising as companies try to rein in costs.
* Alphabet's shares fell nearly 6% in after-hours trading after it reported revenue of $69.1 billion, up 6.1% from the third quarter last year but below what analysts expected. This year's results compare to a 41% gain in sales last year. Earnings were $1.06 a share.
* Search revenue rose 4.3% and YouTube ad revenue fell 0.2%. Combined, Google ad sales missed expectations by more than $2 billion, MarketWatch reported. It was the first time YouTube sales have dropped since 2020.
* Analysts expected earnings of $1.26 a share on total revenue of $71 billion, according to FactSet. CEO Sundar Pichai said the company would take steps, including focusing on products that improve search with artificial intelligence, and scaling back hiring and other costs.
* Revenue from Google cloud rose 38%, to $6.9 billion and was growing at a slightly faster pace than the second quarter, though it ranks behind bigger cloud firms such as Amazon.com.
What's Next: Facebook parent Meta Platforms is scheduled to report its second quarter in a row of declining advertising revenue later today, after the closing bell. Analysts expect revenue of $27.4 billion, according to FactSet, which would fall below the second quarter and the third quarter 2021.
— Liz Moyer 
***
Microsoft's Forecast Disappoints on Cloud Weakness
Microsoft's outlook disappointed investors, sending shares down more than 6% in after-hours trading, as it forecast revenue that would be $2 billion lower than expected for the fiscal second quarter. It reported lower-than-expected revenue growth in its cloud computing division in the first quarter.
* Chief Financial Officer Amy Hood gave a revenue outlook in a range of $52.35 billion to $53.35 billion, while analysts were expecting $56.16 billion. "Intelligent cloud" revenue is now forecast around $21.25 billion to $21.55 billion, while average expectations were $21.82 billion.
* The guidance came after Microsoft reported better-than-expected first-quarter results, with revenue of $50.1 billion, up 11%, and net income of $17.6 billion, down 14%. That was the biggest quarterly net income drop in two years and the lowest revenue growth in five, The Wall Street Journal reported .
* Intelligent cloud includes its Azure segment, where revenue rose 35%, which was slower than the average analyst forecast, according to FactSet. Microsoft's "productivity and business processes" segment, which includes Office and other software, had revenue of $16.5 billion, up 9%.
* Microsoft is reportedly cutting nearly 1,000 jobs across multiple divisions, according to reports last week. "Like all companies, we evaluate our business priorities on a regular basis, and make structural adjustments accordingly," a Microsoft spokeswoman said in a statement to the Journal.
What's Next: While Microsoft's videogame console Xbox had a 3% drop in revenue in the most recent quarter, it could gain more significance down the road. Microsoft is awaiting regulatory approval for its $75 billion deal for Activision Blizzard and wants to close it by next June.
— Eric J. Savitz and Janet H. Cho
***
Pound Recovers on New Prime Minister, Weaker Dollar
The British pound has recovered to levels last seen before last month's fiscal statement, which sent investors fleeing from U.K. assets and toppled former prime minister Liz Truss.
* Sterling briefly rose above $1.16 on Wednesday, its highest level since Sept. 23, when the fiscal plan presented by Truss threw markets into turmoil. New Prime Minister Rishi Sunak distanced himself from the tax-cutting plans of his predecessor after his appointment on Tuesday.
* The rally was partly helped by a weakening of the dollar after data showed U.S. home price growth slowed in August and a fall in U.S. consumer confidence. The U.S. Dollar Index on Wednesday was down 0.8% at 110.09.
* Currencies of countries with looser monetary policies are still close to multidecade lows against the greenback, driven by the Fed's rate-hiking cycle. The Japanese yen on Wednesday traded at 146.98 to the dollar, having last week reached more than 150 to the dollar, its weakest level since 1990. China's yuan fell last Friday to its weakest level against the dollar since 2008.
What's Next: Further currency moves could be driven by investors looking to take advantage of the strong dollar to snap up foreign assets, as well as any hints the Fed could slow rate hikes for fear of driving the U.S. economy into recession, which could weaken the dollar.
—Adam Clark
***
Tennessee, Florida Gulf Coast Still Lure Luxury Home Buyers
Luxury housing spots from during and before the pandemic are holding their own as the rest of the real estate market weakens amid soaring mortgage interest rates, including spots in Tennessee surrounding the city of Nashville and spots along Florida's Gulf Coast.
* The area including Davidson, Murfreesboro and Franklin, Tenn., is the top destination for luxury home buyers for the second straight quarter, according to The Wall Street Journal/Realtor.com Emerging Housing Markets Index for the third quarter. Three other metro areas in the top five were in Florida.
* Although the migration of high-net-worth individuals out of densely populated cities has slowed, it has created opportunities in urban markets, the data found. Places like Nashville offer affordability for buyers from high-cost markets such as New York, Chicago or San Francisco.
* Charleston, N.C., ranked second on the list, followed by Florida markets North Port-Sarasota-Bradenton; Tampa-St. Petersburg-Clearwater; and Naples-Immokalee-Marco Island, respectively.
* Home price growth more broadly slowed in August . The Case-Shiller index tracking home prices nationally was 13% higher than the same month last year, down from an annual gain of 15.6% in July. On a seasonally adjusted basis, the index fell the most since February 2010.
What's Next: The same forces that weighed on home prices this summer are likely to dent year-over-year home price gains in the following months. The National Association of Realtors has said that the median home sale price in September was $384,800, down about 7% from an all-time high in June.
—Liz Moyer
***
Dear Quentin,
My boyfriend owns a house with a 30-year mortgage balance of $150,000 on a 4% interest rate. He has $275,000 in cash and retirement accounts. He is retired.
My house is paid off. I have $50,000 in cash and retirement accounts. I would like to retire within one to two years.
We wish to cohabitate but have not been able to agree on a fair "rent" to pay. He is not willing to live in my house because it has fewer amenities.
He believes I should pay half of his monthly cost at his nicer, more expensive house. He could pay off his mortgage and save $600 a month, but he likes to have cash.
I have foregone that luxury and paid off my mortgage. I am now working on building my savings. I don't feel it is fair for me to pay half of the mortgage interest expense.
I don't know what repair and maintenance costs should be expected from me, if I have no equity in his house. There are many points of view, none of which feels fair.
These are the options he set forth:
· I live in his house and thus get to rent mine out. Pay him half of what I net from that rental.
· Pay half of the actual costs of living expenses and upkeep on his house while I live there.
· Pay him what I pay to live in my current home for taxes, insurance, and utilities: $800/month.
What say you, Moneyist?
—House Owner & Girlfriend

—Quentin Fottrell

title: Elon Musk Says Twitter Won't Be 'Free-for-All Hellscape,' Addressing Advertisers' Concerns; Marketers worry about the Tesla CEO's stance on content moderation, potential conflicts in auto advertising if the Twitter deal completes
content:
Elon Musk is expected to complete a takeover of Twitter Inc. this week, barring a last-minute snag. Madison Avenue isn't sold on the deal.
Advertisers are concerned about the billionaire's plans to soften content moderation and what they say are potential conflicts of interest in auto advertising, given that he is chief executive of Tesla Inc., say people familiar with the situation.
 Mr. Musk said this spring that as owner of Twitter he would reinstate former President Donald Trump's account, which the platform suspended indefinitely after linking Mr. Trump's comments to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot . That would be a red line for some brands, said Kieley Taylor, global head of partnerships at GroupM, a leading ad-buying agency that represents blue-chip brands.
About a dozen of GroupM's clients, which own an array of well-known consumer brands, have told the agency to pause all their ads on Twitter if Mr. Trump's account is reinstated, Ms. Taylor said. Others are in wait-and-see mode. Ms. Taylor said she expects to hear from many more clients if Mr. Trump's account returns.
"That doesn't mean that we won't be entertaining lots of emails and phone calls as soon as a transaction goes through," Ms. Taylor said. "I anticipate we'll be busy."
In a message to advertisers on Twitter on Thursday, Mr. Musk said he was buying the company to "have a common digital town square, where a wide range of beliefs can be debated in a healthy manner." He said Twitter "cannot become a free-for-all hellscape, where anything can be said with no consequences!" Mr. Musk said in addition to following laws, Twitter must be "warm and welcoming to all."
He said Twitter aims to be a platform that "strengthens your brand and grows your enterprise."
Twitter's chief customer officer, Sarah Personette, tweeted that she had a discussion with Mr. Musk on Wednesday evening. "Our continued commitment to brand safety for advertisers remains unchanged," she wrote. "Looking forward to the future!"
Mr. Trump has said he wouldn't rejoin Twitter even if allowed. Representatives for Tesla and Mr. Trump didn't respond to a request for comment.
Mr. Musk is nearing completion of the acquisition of Twitter after a monthslong legal battle in which he tried to back out of the $44 billion deal he agreed to in April. The judge overseeing the legal fight said if the deal doesn't close by Friday she will schedule a November trial.
Twitter sent an email to some ad buyers earlier this week letting them know that the company is working with "the buyer" to close the acquisition by Friday and to acknowledge that Twitter is aware that advertisers have a lot of questions, according to the email, which was reviewed by The Wall Street Journal. The email, which didn't name Mr. Musk, said Twitter would work "with the potential buyer to answer quickly."
Advertising provided 89% of Twitter's $5.08 billion revenue in 2021. Mr. Musk has said he hates advertising. In a series of tweets earlier this year, he suggested Twitter should move toward subscriptions and remove ads from Twitter Blue, a premium program that gives users additional features.
Mr. Musk describes himself as a "free speech absolutist" and has said Twitter should be more cautious about removing tweets or banning users.
Mr. Musk may have reasons to avoid any drastic changes to Twitter's ad business. Twitter will take on $13 billion in debt in the deal. The online ad markets already are shaky, amid concerns about the economy, with Snap Inc. and Alphabet Inc. posting lower-than-expected revenue results for the September quarter .
Like other ad-supported social-media platforms, Twitter provides advertisers with adjacency controls, tools that are meant to ensure ads don't appear next to certain content the brands deem objectionable.
Some ad buyers said Twitter lags behind its competitors in providing so-called brand safety features. Joshua Lowcock, global chief media officer at UM Worldwide, an ad agency owned by Interpublic Group of Cos., called Twitter's adjacency controls inadequate and "poorly thought through."
Ad agency Omnicom Media Group evaluates the major social-media platforms' progress on brand-safety tools every quarter. In July, Omnicom rated Twitter's progress behind that of YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and Reddit, according to a document reviewed by the Journal. Robert Pearsall, managing director of social activation at Omnicom Media Group, said Twitter has made agreements to improve its brand-safety controls to meet Omnicom's standards, but it hasn't introduced those changes to the market yet.
"There are significant concerns about the implications of a possible change to content moderation policy," he said. Twitter has said it is working on tools to give advertisers a better idea of where their ads appear.
Automotive manufacturers have expressed concerns about advertising on Twitter under Mr. Musk's ownership, given his role at electric-vehicle juggernaut Tesla, some ad buyers said. Advertisers often share data with Twitter and other platforms—on their own customers or people that are in the market for a car—to help target their ads at the right people. Some auto companies will be wary of doing so, out of concern that data may leak to Tesla, the buyers said.
Though Twitter relies on ad dollars, it isn't one of the biggest players in the digital ad economy. The company gets about 1.1% of U.S. digital ad spending, according to Insider Intelligence, a much smaller slice than Google, Meta Platforms Inc. or Amazon.com Inc.
Already, there have been signs of anxiety on Madison Avenue about Mr. Musk's takeover of Twitter. In July, the company reported a 1% decrease in second-quarter revenue, which it blamed on uncertainty over the deal as well as broader pressures in the digital ad market.
Given Mr. Musk's past remarks on advertising, some advertisers wonder if Mr. Musk may exit the ad business entirely.
"The question we keep getting asked is: Do we think Musk will turn off ads completely?" said UM Worldwide's Mr. Lowcock.

title: Elon Musk Completes $44 Billion Deal to Own Twitter
content:
In an undated image provided by Delaware Chancery Court, Judge Kathaleen St. J. McCormick, top center, at the Delaware Chancery Court in September. The judge has given Elon Musk until Friday, Oct. 28, 2022, to close his long-promised, $44 billion deal to acquire Twitter. (Delaware Chancery Court via The New York Times) — NO SALES; FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY. —

SAN FRANCISCO — After months of waffling, lawsuits, verbal mudslinging and the near miss of a full-blown trial, Elon Musk now owns Twitter.
On Thursday night, Musk closed his $44 billion deal to buy the social media service, said three people with knowledge of the situation. He also began cleaning house, with at least four top Twitter executives — including the CEO and chief financial officer — getting fired Thursday. Musk had arrived at Twitter’s San Francisco headquarters Wednesday and met with engineers and ad executives.
The closing of the deal, which followed months of drama and legal challenges as Musk changed his mind about buying the company, sets Twitter on an uncertain course. Musk, a self-described “free speech absolutist,” has said that he wants to make the social media platform a more freewheeling place for all types of commentary and that he would “reverse the permanent ban” of former President Donald Trump from the service.
Musk’s open approach to speech on Twitter could exacerbate long-simmering issues of toxic content and misinformation, affecting political debates around the world. Early tests will come within days, when Brazil elects its president and American voters go to the polls Nov. 8 for the midterm elections. Twitter said it would prohibit misleading claims about voting and the outcome of elections, but that was before Musk owned it.
“There could be real-world consequences to his leadership,” David Kaye, a law professor at the University of California, Irvine, who worked with the United Nations on issues of free speech, said of Musk’s ownership of Twitter. “To the extent that world leaders see they have this space and it’s unmoderated, they could push to see how far they can go.”
The acquisition has been celebrated by some Republicans, who have argued that Twitter censored conservative viewpoints. Researchers have said Twitter’s rules have been essential to countering online hate speech and disinformation. Some advertisers have worried about allowing their brands to appear alongside controversial tweets.

“It’s a ‘back-to-the-future’ reversion to content rules circa 2010, but one that ignores the lived experience over the last decade,” said Colin Crowell, Twitter’s former head of global public policy, who left the company in 2019. “People eventually realize that the Wild West needs a sheriff, both for ensuring the safety of citizens but also for enhancing the prospects for commerce.”

Musk has promised other sweeping changes at Twitter, including new leadership, job cuts and the pursuit of new ways to make money. Twitter, which employs more than 7,500 people, has had difficulties consistently growing its advertising-based business and attracting new users. The firings of the top company executives Thursday were a sign that Musk intended to move swiftly.
Musk, 51, will be remaking Twitter without having to disclose how it is performing every few months. By taking the company private, he does not need to regularly answer to shareholders and can make changes to the service away from the public’s prying eyes.
Musk, who also runs electric carmaker Tesla and rocket company SpaceX, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Completing the deal was a victory for Twitter’s board. When Musk agreed to pay $54.20 a share for the company in April, Twitter faced criticism for accepting a price that was too low. But, as the global economy faltered in the ensuing months and Twitter’s stock fell, the deal price appeared to be a win for shareholders, and the board sought to force Musk to abide by the agreement.
A Twitter spokesperson did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
The Twitter executives who were fired Thursday include Parag Agrawal, the CEO; Ned Segal, the chief financial officer; Vijaya Gadde, the top legal and policy executive; and Sean Edgett, the general counsel, said two people with knowledge of the matter. At least one of the executives who was fired was escorted out of Twitter’s office, they said.
Musk, who is one of Twitter’s most active users and has more than 109 million followers, began accumulating shares in the company this year. In April, he struck the deal to buy the company for $44 billion and said he would lift Twitter’s content moderation policies, eliminate spam, add new features and provide more transparency about the algorithms used to promote content.
“Twitter has tremendous potential — I look forward to working with the company and the community of users to unlock it,” he said in a statement in April.
But, within weeks, he began questioning the deal. Musk lashed out at the Twitter executives responsible for content decisions and accused the company of failing to accurately count the spam accounts on its platform. When Agrawal tried debunking Musk’s claims, Musk responded by tweeting a poop emoji.
By July, Musk had decided that he no longer wanted to own Twitter, arguing that he had been misled about the amount of spam on the platform. He announced his intent to abandon the acquisition.
Twitter sued Musk to force him to carry out the agreement. The company accused Musk of trying to back out of the deal because the economic downturn had caused a decline in his personal wealth. Musk had agreed to personally provide roughly $33 billion of the $44 billion deal.
The lawsuit ended up in Delaware Chancery Court, which hears many corporate cases. The court set a five-day trial in mid-October to hear the case.
But facing days of depositions and an uncertain outcome, Musk reconsidered. He tried negotiating a discount on the deal price. Those discussions were unsuccessful. This month, Musk said he would proceed with the acquisition at the original price if Twitter halted its legal battle against him.
The judge overseeing Twitter’s lawsuit agreed to put the case on hold until Oct. 28, giving Musk three weeks to close the deal.
Musk has set some ambitious goals for Twitter, which he has said he will transform into an “everything app” called X. In presentations to investors about the deal this spring, he said he anticipated that Twitter would reach annual revenue of $26.4 billion and have 931 million users by 2028. The company reported $5.08 billion in revenue last year and had more than 200 million users.
Musk has suggested that cuts could be necessary to limit Twitter’s costs. Many of the company’s employees could face layoffs. In recent days, Twitter has tried soothing its workforce, asking employees to ignore reports of potential layoffs.

Twitter’s performance will be vital as Musk balances investing in the company’s future and paying off interest on the $12.5 billion in loans he took out to finance the deal. Analysts have questioned whether Twitter can bear the burden of those payments given its patchy profits.
Those loans will also stand as a pain point for the investment banks that cobbled them together, as the market for such loans has dropped precipitously since Musk announced his bid in April.

Advertisers may also be wary of doing business with Musk after he denounced the use of advertising on Twitter and said the company should find a different source of revenue. Some advertisers have also been skeptical about their brands appearing alongside risky content that Musk has said should be allowed on Twitter, while others have preferred to spend money with social networks like Facebook and TikTok.
On Thursday, Musk sought to quell advertiser concerns with an open letter suggesting some content moderation would continue.
“Twitter obviously cannot become a free-for-all hellscape, where anything can be said with no consequences,” he wrote. “Twitter aspires to be the most respected advertising platform in the world.”
This article originally appeared in The New York Times.

The judge has given Elon Musk until Friday, Oct. 28, 2022, to close his long-promised, $44 billion deal to acquire Twitter. title: Musk dubs himself 'Chief Twit,' visits Twitter's offices
content:
SAN FRANCISCO - Elon Musk is on track to buy Twitter. For real this time.
The world's richest person showed up at Twitter's San Francisco headquarters Wednesday for meetings with executives and changed his bio on Twitter to "Chief Twit."
The moves signal the $44 billion deal is on track to close this week, something echoed by people close with Musk who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters. Financing is lining up to finalize the deal.
Twitter's stock closed at $53.35 - just under Musk's offer of $54.20, signaling the market believes it will go through, too.
It's a far cry from just a few weeks ago, when Twitter and Musk were locked in litigation after the Tesla chief executive attempted to back out of his deal to acquire the social media company, citing problems with spam and bots.
On his Twitter account Wednesday, Musk praised the company's capacity for enabling "citizen journalism" and said entities such as local news organizations "should get way more prominence" on the site.
Twitter's chief marketing officer, Leslie Berland, sent an email to staff Wednesday morning saying Musk would be in the San Francisco offices and encouraged employees to "say hi," according to a copy viewed by The Washington Post.
Musk later tweeted a video showing him walking into the company's reception area.
Twitter spokeswoman Rebecca Hahn confirmed a companywide communication that said Musk would address the company on Friday.
Musk is funding a large portion of the deal through debt from a group of seven major banks. Spokespeople for Bank of America, BNP Paribas and Societe Generale did not respond to a request for comment. Spokespeople for Barclays, Morgan Stanley, Mizuho and MUFG declined to comment.
Musk's team was pitching investors throughout the weekend, the people said, as they looked to lessen his financial burden in the deal.
Musk shifted his opinion on whether to buy the company after a series of losses in Delaware Chancery Court in matters related to scheduling and discovery, according to the people close to Musk and his team. A loss became a serious possibility if the matter went to trial, risking penalties beyond merely the buying cost. And the blows to Tesla's stock and Musk's net worth became a lingering concern.
Musk acknowledged overpaying for the site during Tesla's earnings call last week.
Musk also took solace in his debt and equity commitments, which locked him into the deal on favorable terms that might not be otherwise available, the people said. And he became excited by his plans for the site.
The Post reported last week that Musk laid out plans to lay off nearly three-fourths of Twitter's staff as he seeks to implement aggressive cost-cutting and loosen the site's content moderation standards.
The initial phase of his ownership will focus on talent - and Musk is expected to look to his other companies, Tesla and SpaceX, to seek out specialists who might help Twitter reverse its fortunes, the people said.
Gerrit De Vynck and Elizabeth Dwoskin contributed to this report.

title: Musk Reassures Advertisers About His Twitter Plans
content:
On the eve of his $44 billion Twitter acquisition's expected close, Elon Musk sought to reassure advertisers about his plans for the social media app.
The Tesla (ticker: TSLA) CEO said in an open letter to Twitter advertisers that most of the speculation about why he bought Twitter and what he thinks about advertising is wrong. He also clarified that the platform, "obviously cannot become a free-for-all hellscape, where anything can be said with no consequences!"
"Fundamentally, Twitter aspires to be the most respected advertising platform in the world that strengthens your brand and grows your enterprise," Musk wrote.
Twitter Chief Customer Officer Sarah Personette shared Musk's post and said she had a "great discussion" with the billionaire.
"Our continued commitment to brand safety for advertisers remains unchanged," she added. "Looking forward to the future!"
Musk's post comes as advertisers and industry experts have tried to grapple with Musk's stated plans for a Twitter as a "digital town square" with fears from brands that their ads could be displayed near objectionable but legal content.
The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday that some advertisers are indeed worried about Musk's potential impact on moderation. Kieley Taylor, global head of partnerships at ad-buying agency GroupM, told the Journal that a dozen of its clients have told the agency to pause ads on Twitter if former President Donald Trump is reinstated. Trump was suspended from Twitter following the Jan. 6 Capitol Riot, but Musk has said he would undo the ban. The Journal described GroupM's clients as "an array of well-known consumer brands."
Twitter stock was up 1.1% to $53.96 Thursday, which should be its final day of trading. That is just a tick below the $54.20 that Twitter stockholders will receive from Musk for each share they own. The New York Stock Exchange says on its website that Twitter trading will be suspended before the market's open on Friday, ahead of Musk's 5 p.m. deadline to close the deal. 
Musk seems to be on track. He retweeted a photo shared by biographer Walter Isaacson of himself holding court at the coffee bar at Twitter's office. Multiple outlets reported Musk is set to address employees on Friday.
Write to Connor Smith at [email protected]

title: Elon Musk Says Twitter Won't Be 'Free-for-All Hellscape,' Addressing Advertisers' Concerns; Marketers worry about the Tesla CEO's stance on content moderation, potential conflicts in auto advertising if the Twitter deal completes
content:
Madison Avenue isn't sold on Elon Musk's takeover of Twitter Inc.
Advertisers are concerned about the billionaire's plans to soften content moderation and what they say are potential conflicts of interest in auto advertising, given that he is chief executive of Tesla Inc., say people familiar with the situation.
 Mr. Musk said this spring that as owner of Twitter he would reinstate former President Donald Trump's account, which the platform suspended indefinitely after linking Mr. Trump's comments to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot . That would be a red line for some brands, said Kieley Taylor, global head of partnerships at GroupM, a leading ad-buying agency that represents blue-chip brands.
About a dozen of GroupM's clients, which own an array of well-known consumer brands, have told the agency to pause all their ads on Twitter if Mr. Trump's account is reinstated, Ms. Taylor said. Others are in wait-and-see mode. Ms. Taylor said she expects to hear from many more clients if Mr. Trump's account returns.
"That doesn't mean that we won't be entertaining lots of emails and phone calls as soon as a transaction goes through," Ms. Taylor said. "I anticipate we'll be busy."
In a message to advertisers on Twitter on Thursday, Mr. Musk said he was buying the company to "have a common digital town square, where a wide range of beliefs can be debated in a healthy manner." He said Twitter "cannot become a free-for-all hellscape, where anything can be said with no consequences!" Mr. Musk said in addition to following laws, Twitter must be "warm and welcoming to all."
He said Twitter aims to be a platform that "strengthens your brand and grows your enterprise."
Twitter's chief customer officer, Sarah Personette, tweeted that she had a discussion with Mr. Musk on Wednesday evening. "Our continued commitment to brand safety for advertisers remains unchanged," she wrote. "Looking forward to the future!"
Mr. Trump has said he wouldn't rejoin Twitter even if allowed. Representatives for Tesla and Mr. Trump didn't respond to a request for comment.
Mr. Musk has completed the acquisition of Twitter, according to people familiar with the matter, after a monthslong legal battle in which he tried to back out of the $44 billion deal he agreed to in April. The judge overseeing the legal fight had said if the deal didn't close by Friday she would schedule a November trial.
Twitter sent an email to some ad buyers earlier this week letting them know that the company is working with "the buyer" to close the acquisition by Friday and to acknowledge that Twitter is aware that advertisers have a lot of questions, according to the email, which was reviewed by The Wall Street Journal. The email, which didn't name Mr. Musk, said Twitter would work "with the potential buyer to answer quickly."
Advertising provided 89% of Twitter's $5.08 billion revenue in 2021. Mr. Musk has said he hates advertising. In a series of tweets earlier this year, he suggested Twitter should move toward subscriptions and remove ads from Twitter Blue, a premium program that gives users additional features.
Mr. Musk describes himself as a "free speech absolutist" and has said Twitter should be more cautious about removing tweets or banning users.
Mr. Musk may have reasons to avoid any drastic changes to Twitter's ad business. Twitter will take on $13 billion in debt in the deal. The online-ad markets already are shaky, amid concerns about the economy, with Snap Inc. and Alphabet Inc. posting lower-than-expected revenue results for the September quarter .
Like other ad-supported social-media platforms, Twitter provides advertisers with adjacency controls, tools that are meant to ensure ads don't appear next to certain content the brands deem objectionable.
Some ad buyers said Twitter lags behind its competitors in providing so-called brand safety features. Joshua Lowcock, global chief media officer at UM Worldwide, an ad agency owned by Interpublic Group of Cos., called Twitter's adjacency controls inadequate and "poorly thought through."
Ad agency Omnicom Media Group evaluates the major social-media platforms' progress on brand-safety tools every quarter. In July, Omnicom rated Twitter's progress behind that of YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and Reddit, according to a document reviewed by the Journal. Robert Pearsall, managing director of social activation at Omnicom Media Group, said Twitter has made agreements to improve its brand-safety controls to meet Omnicom's standards, but it hasn't introduced those changes to the market yet.
"There are significant concerns about the implications of a possible change to content moderation policy," he said. Twitter has said it is working on tools to give advertisers a better idea of where their ads appear.
Automotive manufacturers have expressed concerns about advertising on Twitter under Mr. Musk's ownership, given his role at electric-vehicle juggernaut Tesla, some ad buyers said. Advertisers often share data with Twitter and other platforms—on their own customers or people that are in the market for a car—to help target their ads at the right people. Some auto companies will be wary of doing so, out of concern that data may leak to Tesla, the buyers said.
Though Twitter relies on ad dollars, it isn't one of the biggest players in the digital-ad economy. The company gets about 1.1% of U.S. digital-ad spending, according to Insider Intelligence, a much smaller slice than Google, Meta Platforms Inc. or Amazon.com Inc.
Already, there have been signs of anxiety on Madison Avenue about Mr. Musk's takeover of Twitter. In July, the company reported a 1% decrease in second-quarter revenue, which it blamed on uncertainty over the deal as well as broader pressures in the digital ad market.
Given Mr. Musk's past remarks on advertising, some advertisers wonder if Mr. Musk may exit the ad business entirely.
"The question we keep getting asked is: Do we think Musk will turn off ads completely?" said UM Worldwide's Mr. Lowcock.
Write to Patience Haggin at [email protected] and Suzanne Vranica at [email protected] 
 Elon Musk Says Twitter Won't Be 'Free-for-All Hellscape,' Addressing Advertisers' Concerns 
Credit: By Patience Haggin and Suzanne Vranica

title: Elon Musk Takes Twitter, and Tech Deals, to Another Level
content:
FILE — Elon Musk in lower Manhattan on April 4, 2022. Twitter has filed documents asking to remove its shares from the New York Stock Exchange, the first official step toward becoming a private company under Musk’s ownership. (Jefferson Siegel/The New York Times)
Forget about the endless drama, the bots, the abrupt reversals, the spectacle, the alleged risk to the republic and all we hold dear. Here is the most important thing about Elon Musk’s buying Twitter: The moguls have been unleashed.
In the old days, when a tech tycoon wanted to buy something big, he needed a company to do it. Steve Case used AOL to buy Time Warner. Jeff Bezos bought Whole Foods for Amazon. Mark Zuckerberg used Facebook to buy Instagram and WhatsApp and Oculus and on and on. These were corporate deals done for the bottom line, even if they might never have happened without a famous and forceful proprietor.
Musk’s $44 billion takeover of Twitter, which finally became a reality Thursday, six months after he agreed to the deal, is different. It is an individual buying something for himself that 240 million people around the world use regularly. While he has other investors, Musk will have absolute control over the fate of the short-message social media platform.
It’s a difficult deal to evaluate even in an industry built on deals, because this one is so unusual. It came about whimsically, impulsively. But, even by the standards of Silicon Valley, where billions are casually offered for fledging operations — and even by the wallet of Musk, on most days the richest man in the world — $44 billion is quite a chunk of change.
Buying Twitter is also an overwhelmingly brash action — a belief that a communications platform that has defied all efforts to become seriously profitable, and that has been ensnared in controversy about the limits of speech almost since its founding in 2006, can be easily fixed by one person.
If you have billions of dollars these days, however, belief in yourself is never in short supply.
Musk’s fortune comes from the electric carmaker Tesla, which he turned into the leading vehicle for changing how Americans drive, an uphill task if there ever was one. Musk and Bezos are separately vying to re-create the space program, which in the 1960s was deemed too important and too expensive to be run by anything except the federal government.
Zuckerberg has changed Facebook’s name to Meta and reoriented the company to create a virtual world where people will henceforth “live.” Peter Thiel, who co-founded the payments firm PayPal and was an early investor in Facebook, has become the midterm elections’ most prominent campaign contributor, pumping tens of millions of dollars into right-wing congressional candidates. Two of his former employees are the Republican nominees for senator in Ohio and Arizona.
Richard Walker, a professor emeritus of economic geography at the University of California, Berkeley and a historian of Silicon Valley, sees a shift in the locus of power.
“In this new Gilded Age, we’re being battered by billionaires rather than the corporations that were the face of the 20th century,” he said. “And the tech titans are leading the way.”

Even people who have been watching the tech scene closely for decades are stumped for precedents for Musk’s buying Twitter.
“Most of the guys built great companies, retired and created giant foundations to give away their money,” said Michael S. Malone, who has written histories of Apple, Intel and other companies. “Nobody has done something like this.” He counts himself a fan of Musk’s loosening of Twitter’s rules, though: “Making the place wide open will make it even crazier and more fun.”

Musk, who disbanded Tesla’s public relations department, didn’t respond to a message for comment.
Rich people have long wanted to own media properties, a tradition the tech titans have continued. Bezos bought The Washington Post for $250 million. Marc Benioff of Salesforce owns Time magazine. Pierre Omidyar of eBay developed a homegrown media empire.
Deals have been a feature of Silicon Valley as long as there has been a Silicon Valley. Often they fail, especially when the acquisition was made for technology that either quickly grew outdated or never really worked at all. At least one venerable company, Hewlett-Packard, followed that strategy and has practically faded away.
Dealogic, a data firm, compiled for The New York Times a list of the top 10 biggest tech deals since 1995 by deal value. By that measure, Musk’s purchase of Twitter is No. 10. Microsoft’s $70 billion-plus acquisition of Activision Blizzard, which is pending, has garnered a fraction of the attention despite being No. 2.
Activision Blizzard is merely a video game company. Musk has maintained from the beginning that buying Twitter isn’t a trophy or a game or a scheme to increase his net worth. Instead, he has cast it in the grandest terms possible.
“Having a public platform that is maximally trusted and broadly inclusive is extremely important to the future of civilization,” the entrepreneur said in April after sealing the deal. “I don’t care about the economics at all.”
He cared a little more when the subsequent plunge in the stock market meant that he was overpaying by a significant amount. Analysts estimated that Twitter was worth not $44 billion but $30 billion, or maybe even less. For a few months, Musk tried to get out of the deal.

This had the paradoxical effect of bringing the transaction down to earth for spectators. Who among us has not failed to do due diligence on a new venture — a job, a house, even a relationship — and then realized that it was going to cost so much more than we had thought? Musk’s buying Twitter, and then his refusal to buy Twitter, and then his being forced to buy Twitter after all — and everything playing out on Twitter — was weirdly relatable.
Inescapable, too. The apex, or perhaps the nadir, came this month when Musk introduced a perfume called Burnt Hair, described on its website as “the Essence of Repugnant Desire.”
“Please buy my perfume, so I can buy Twitter,” Musk tweeted on Oct. 12, garnering nearly 600,000 likes. This worked, apparently; the perfume is now marked “sold out” on its site. Did 30,000 people really pay $100 each for a bottle? Will this perfume actually be produced and sold? (It’s not supposed to be released until next year.) It’s hard to tell where the joke stops, which is perhaps the point.

Walker, the author of “Pictures of a Gone City: Tech and the Dark Side of Prosperity in the San Francisco Bay Area,” fears for the future.
“There’s no counterbalance to the new business moguls,” he said. “Unions, fraternal organizations and local media have been greatly weakened. The general public is cut off from these positive influences and awash in misinformation.”
If Musk’s buying Twitter signifies the beginning of something, it also, in another way, represents an ending. The other social media platforms are closely held by their founders through their companies’ share structures. No one could buy Facebook away from Zuckerberg without his agreement, or Snap from its chief co-founder, Evan Spiegel.
“What was unique about Twitter was that no one actually controlled it,” said Richard Greenfield, a media analyst at LightShed Partners. “And now one person will own it in its entirety.”
He is relatively hopeful, however, that Musk will improve the site, somehow. That, in turn, will have its own consequences.
“If it turns into a massive home run,” Greenfield said, “you’ll see other billionaires try to do the same thing.”
This article originally appeared in The New York Times.
